awd_titl_txt: OAC Core: Small:  Collaborative Research: Data Provenance Infrastructure towards Robust andReliable Data Sharing and Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapidly increasing number of interconnected devices and systems brings unprecedented collaborative opportunities between researchers, business partners, and healthcare organizations that can extend discoveries beyond those derivable from any single study. For instance, data sharing between various medical organizations can enhance understanding of the results from an individual clinical by polling of results from various trials from multiple organizations, and thus it enables extending the analysis of treatment options and accelerating biomedical research. While a vast amount of data collected from various sources brings us benefits, it imposes, at the same time, an important challenge of ensuring trustworthiness and quality of data due to the integration of disparate data from various sources. Furthermore, faulty, improperly configured, or broken sensors, as well as buggy or compromised data processing units, can severely affect the quality of data and the analyzed results. This project proposes to develop an infrastructure that provides robust, fine-grain, and end-to-end provenance for collaborative data sharing and analytics. The outcome of this research will directly serve as the foundation of trustworthy data sharing and analytic infrastructures by providing robust and attack/fault-resilient fine-grain provenance of the shared data by creating fine-grain end-to-end data provenance framework for diverse communication infrastructures.

In this project, the PIs will develop an end-to-end data provenance framework that provides robust and fine-grain data lineage for trustworthy data sharing and analytic infrastructures. First, they will develop a scalable and reliable infrastructure for collecting data provenance for distributed interconnected devices that can derive a concise provenance data in various environments of distributed devices (e.g., devices using diverse hardware and software platforms). Next, they will design and implement a framework to enable proper derivation and propagation of fine-grain provenance records for data sharing, processing, and analytics. It will provide services for provenance tracking as well as provenance record processing when the data are aggregated, analyzed, and processed (e.g., merge, split, duplicate, delete, extract, or statistical analytics). The PIs also plan to develop a system that can analyze and visualize the complete lineage of data to measure the quality of data and conduct various root cause analyses to identify the fundamental reasons behind data quality issues. The system will be capable of handling a large amount of data generated over a long period of time across multiple devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
[1] Project Description

This project aims to develop an infrastructure for robust, fine-grained, end-to-end data provenance, supporting trustworthy data sharing and analytics in distributed systems. The proposed framework addresses challenges posed by the integration of disparate data from interconnected devices and systems, ensuring data quality and trustworthiness. 

 

[2] Project Outcomes and Findings

This project is a collaborative project with the University of Georgia. This report focuses on the effort of the University of Virginia.

 

Year 1 (2019~2020)

The PI focused on creating forensics primitives.

C2SR (NDSS'21) proposes a technique to reconstruct past executions for forensic investigations. Using an interactive partial execution method enables investigators to reproduce specific segments of long-running recorded executions, aiding in root cause analysis. The approach facilitates concrete execution replay to understand incidents and verify the accuracy of collected provenance data.

The PI designed a cyber forensics course focused on hands-on program analysis for recovering evidence from binaries and memory dumps, using Pin and LLVM for dynamic and static analysis, including malware unpacking and obfuscation.

Year 2 (2020~2021)

The PI focused on conducting security testing of various systems during this period. In addition, the PI also conducted student advising efforts for the national security competitions.

The PI conducted two projects on security and reliability: Certificate Authorities in HTTPS Phishing (ASIACCS’21), analyzing CA security in phishing campaigns, and TLS 1.3 in Practice (WWW’21), evaluating TLS 1.3’s improvements in cryptographic security, handshake efficiency, and protection mechanisms.

The PI advised the UVA student security team that competed in the National Collegiate Cyber Defense Competition (CCDC), a defense-focused cybersecurity event emphasizing forensic capabilities, attack analysis, and recovery strategies. The team also developed Bluespawn, a forensic-focused incident response technique. Both the technical report and source code are publicly available at GitHub and University of Virginia's Libra repository.

Year 3 (2021~2022)

The PI continues to focus on conducting security testing of various systems during this period.

The PI conducted two projects to enhance security in IoT/CPS systems: SwarmBug (FSE’21), a debugging system for swarm robotics that fixes configuration bugs in swarm algorithms, and Spinner (CCS’21), a dynamic randomization technique to prevent command injection attacks in IoT web interfaces.

With the insights and findings, the team obtained the capability of protecting critical infrastructure and conducting root cause analysis for forensic analysis.

Year 4 (2022~2023)

During this period, the PI continues to focus on conducting security testing of various systems and understanding complex malicious software systems.

1. Ambitr (ICSE’22) uses an Ambiguous Translator to protect critical components, requiring a secret key to reveal the correct output, making reverse engineering difficult. The research was extended into an attack model and published in WISA’22, where it won the best paper award.

2. SwarmFlawFinder (S&P’22) detects logical flaws in swarm robotics algorithms using feedback-guided fuzz testing, identifying 42 vulnerabilities that could be exploited by adversaries.

3. SynthDB (NDSS’23) enhances security testing for PHP web applications by generating realistic databases, increasing code and query coverage by 14% and 24%, respectively, leading to the discovery of 33 previously unknown vulnerabilities.

4. Additionally, the PI has developed cyber forensics assignments for students, teaching program analysis with projects like modifying a Flappybird game to create hacks and analyzing memory to solve a Minesweeper game.

Year 5 (2023~2024)

The PI has focused efforts on consolidating ongoing work to develop provenance systems based on the insights and findings from the project. A repository has been created to store the various provenance techniques alongside additional repositories dedicated to the individual projects.

PyFET (S&P'23) improves Python binary decompilation by using Forensically Equivalent Transformation (FET), which converts problematic binaries into decompilable ones. It successfully fixed over 77,000 errors in 17,117 real-world Python malware samples, enhancing forensic analysis.

Regarding the effort of provenance technique. We made two contributions: (1) enhancing provenance security for cloud systems and (2) creating repository for provenance related artifacts (https://gitlab.com/yonghwi.kwon/provenance-system).

 

[3] Summary

Over the course of five years, the PI's work has made efforts in advancing cyber forensics, security testing, and provenance systems. To name a few, the team developed forensics primitives like C2SR, which enables cybercrime scene reconstruction for forensic analysis. PyFET was another important forensic capability that can aid existing decompilers for forensic analysis. A significant amount of effort was made to systematically test various systems from the web to CPS: SwarmBug, SwarmFlawFinder, Ambitr, SynthDB, and BFTDetector. The team gained a substantial understanding of security issues in various systems, leading to building secure provenance infrastructure. In particular, the team created a secure configurator for Cloud to improve cloud security by automating the detection and resolution of logging system issues. It addresses vulnerabilities and missing log details, enhancing security by configuring alerts for missing logs and updating vulnerable packages. Last but not least, the Provenance System Repository (https://gitlab.com/yonghwi.kwon/provenance-system) consolidates tools aimed at securing provenance data in cloud and Linux environments.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2024
Modified by: Yonghwi Kwon

This project aims to develop an infrastructure for robust, fine-grained, end-to-end data provenance, supporting trustworthy data sharing and analytics in distributed systems. The proposed framework addresses challenges posed by the integration of disparate data from interconnected devices and systems, ensuring data quality and trustworthiness.





[2] Project Outcomes and Findings


This project is a collaborative project with the University of Georgia. This report focuses on the effort of the University of Virginia.





Year 1 (2019~2020)

With the insights and findings, the team obtained the capability of protecting critical infrastructure and conducting root cause analysis for forensic analysis.

2. SwarmFlawFinder (S&P22) detects logical flaws in swarm robotics algorithms using feedback-guided fuzz testing, identifying 42 vulnerabilities that could be exploited by adversaries.
